publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Flourish. Enter Astorax King of Paphos, his Sister Calis, traine, and Cleanthe, Lucippe Gentlewomen at one doore; At the other Eumenes a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: HEalth to my Soveraigne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Eumenes, welcome:
Welcome to Paphos souldier to our love,
And that faire health ye wish us through the Campe
May it disperse it selfe, and make all happy;
How does the Generall, the valiant Memnon,
And how his wars, Eumenes?

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: The Gods have giv'n you (royall Sir) a Souldier
Better ne're sought a danger, more approv'd
In way of war, more master of his fortunes,
Expert in leading 'em; in doing valiant,
In following all his deeds to Victories,
And holding fortune certaine there.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O Souldier,
Thou speak'st a man indeed; a Generall Generall,
A soule conceiv'd a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Ten set Battells
Against the strong usurper Diocles
Whom long experience had begot a Leader
Ambition rais'd too mighty: hath your Memnon
Won, and won gloriously, distrest and shooke him
Even from the head of all his hopes to nothing:
In three he beat the thunder-bolt his brother
Forc'd him to wall himselfe up: there not safe,
Shooke him with warlike Engines like an earthquake,
Till like a snaile he left his shell and crawl'd
By night, and hidious darknesse to destruction:
Disarm'd for ever rising more; twelve Castles,
Some though impregnable; Townes twice as many
Countries that like the wind knew no command
But savage wildnesse; hath this Generall
With losse of blood & youth, through storms & tempests
Cal'd to your faire obedience. Drum within.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O my Souldier
That thou wert now within my arms; what drums- Drum
Are those that beat Eumenes?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: His my Soveraigne;
Himselfe i'th head of conquest drawing home,
An old man now to offer up his glories,
And endlesse conquest at your shrine,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Goe all,
And entertaine him with all Ceremonie,
Wee'le keep him now a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Sir, a strange one,
Pray God his language beare it; by my life, Sir
He knowes no complement, nor curious casting
Of words into fit places ere he speak 'em,
He can say fight well fellow, and I'le thanke thee:
He that must eat, must sweat; bring up the reare there,
Or charge that wing of horse home. Florish.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Goe too, goe too. Ent. Memnon and a traine of Courtiers & souldiers, two Captains, Chilax.
Valiant and wise are twins Sir: welcome, welcome,
Welcome my fortunate and famous Generall,
High in thy Princes favour as in fame,
Welcome to Peace and Paphos.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thanke your Grace,
And would to God my dull tongue had that sweetnesse
To thanke you as I should; but pardon me,
My sword and I speake roughly Sir: your battells
I dare well say, I have fought well; for I bring ye
That lazie end you wish for Peace, so fully,
That no more name of war is: who now thinkes
Sooner or safer these might have bin ended.
Begin 'em If ye dare againe; I'le thanke him.
Souldier and Souldiers Mate these twenty five yeares,
At length your Generall, (as one whose merit
Durst looke upon no lesse,) I have waded through
Dangers would damp't these soft soules, but to heare of
The maidenheads of thousand lives hangs here Sir,
Since which time, Prince, I know no Court but Marshall,
No oylie language, but the shock of Armes,
No dalliance but with death; No lofty measures
But weary and sad marches, cold and hunger,
Larums at midnight, Valours selfe would shake at,
Yet I ne're shrunke. Balls of consuming Wildfire,
That lickt men up like lightning, have I laught at,
And tost 'em back againe like childrens trifles
Upon the edges of my Enemies swords
I have marcht like whirle-windes, fury at this hand waiting,
Death at my right; Fortune my forlorne hope,
When I have grapled with destruction,
And tug'd with pale fac'd Ruine, Night and Mischiefe,
Frighted to see a new day breake in bloud,
And every where I conquer'd; and for you sir,
Mothers have wanted wombes to make me famous,
And blowne ambition dangers; Those that griev'd ye,
I have taken order for i'th' earth: those fooles
That shall hereafter.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: No more wars my souldier: K. takes Mem. aside and talkes with him.
We must now treat of peace sir.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: How he talkes,
How gloriously.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: A goodly timber'd fellow,
Valiant no doubt.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: If valour dwell in vaunting;
In what a phrase he speakes as if his actions
Could be set of in nothing but a noise,
Sure has a drum in's mouth.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I wonder wenches
How he would speake to us.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Nothing but larum
Tell us whose throat he cut, shew us his sword,
And blesse it for sure biting.

sp.speaker: Lucippe.
sp.l: And t like your Grace,
I doe not thinke he knowes us what we are,
Or to what end; for I have heard his followers
Affirme he never saw a woman that exceeded
A Sutlers wife yet, or in execution
Old bedrid Beldames without teeth or tongues,
That would not flie his furie? how he lookes.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: This way devoutly.

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.l: Sure his Lordship's viewing
Our Fortifications.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: If he mount at me,
I may chance choake his Battery.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Still his eye
Keeps quarter this way: Venus grant his valour
Be not in love.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: If he be, presently
Expect a Herrald and a Trompet with ye
To bid ye render; we two Perdu's pay for't else.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I'le leave ye to my sister, and these Ladies
To make your welcome fuller: my good souldier
We must now turne your sternnesse into Courtship
When ye have done there; to your fair repose sir: Florish.
I know you need it Memnon, welcome gentlemen. Ex. Ki.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Now he begins to march: Madam the Van's yours,
Keep your ground sure; 'tis for your spurrs.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: O Venus. He kneeles amaz'd and forgets to speake.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How he stares on me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Knight him Madam, knight him
He will grow tooth 'ground els.

sp.speaker: Eumenes.
sp.l: Speake sir, 'tis the Princesse.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.l: Ye shame your selfe, speake to her

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Rise and speake sir.
Ye are welcome to the Court, to me, to all sir,

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Is he not deafe?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: The Gentleman's not well.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Fie noble Generall,

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Give him fresh aire his colour goes, how do ye?
The Princesse will be glad sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Peace, and heare me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Command a silence there.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I love thee Lady.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I thank your Lordship heartily: proceed sir.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Lord how it stuck in's stomack like a surfet.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: It breaks apace now from him, God be thanked,
What a fine spoken man he is.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: A choice one of singular variety in carriage.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Yes and I warrant you he knows his distance.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: With all my heart I love thee.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: A hearty gentleman,
And I were eene an arrand beast, my Lord,
But I lov'd you againe.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Good Lady kisse me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: I marry, Mars, there thou cam'st close up to her.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Kiss you at first my Lord, 'tis no faire fashion,
Our lips are like Rose buds, blowne with mens breaths,
They loose both sap and savour; there's my hand sir.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Fie, fie, my Lord, this is too rude.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Unhand me,
Consume me if I hurt her; good sweet Lady
Let me but looke upon thee.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Doe.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yet.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Well sir.
Take your full view.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Blesse your eyes sir.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Mercie,
Is this the man they talkt of for a souldier,
So absolute and Excellent: O the Gods,
If I were given to that vanitie
Of making sport with men for ignorance,
What a most precious subject had I purchas'd?
Speake for him gentlemen: some one that knowes,
What the man ailes; and can speake sense.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Sure Madam,
This fellow has been a rare Hare finder
See how his eyes are set.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Some one goe with me,
I'le send him something, for his head, poore gentleman,
Is troubled with the staggers.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Keep him darke,
He will run March mad else, the fumes of Battell's
Ascend into his braines,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Clap to his feet
An old Drum head, to draw the thunder downward.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Look to him gentlemen: farwell, Lord I am sorry
We cannot kisse at this time, but believe it
Wee'le find an houre for all: God keep my children,
From being such sweet Souldiers; Softly wenches,
Lest we disturbe his dreame. Exit Calis & Ladies.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Why this is Monstrous.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.l: A strange forgetfulnesse, yet still he holds it.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.l: Though he ne're saw a woman of great fashion
Before this day, yet my thinks 'tis possible
He might imagine what they are, and what
Belongs unto 'em; meere report of others.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Pish, his head had other whimsies in't: my Lord,
Death I think y'are strook dumb; my good Lord Generall

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: That I doe love ye Madam; and so love ye
An't like your grace.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: He has bin studying this speech.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Who doe ye speake to sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why where's the Lady
The woman, the faire woman.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: Who?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: The Princesse,
Give me the Princesse.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Give yee counsell rather
To use her like a Princesse: Fy my Lord,
How have you borne your selfe, how nakedly
Laid your soule open: and your ignorance
To be a sport to all; report and honour;
Drew her to doe you favours, and you bluntly,
Without consideration what, or how she was
Neither collecting reason, nor distinction.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why, what did I my masters?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: All that shewes
A man unhandsome, undigested done.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Did not I kneele unto her?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Dumbe and senslesse,
As though ye had bin cut out for your fathers tombe,
Or stuck a land-marke; when she spoke unto you,
Being the excellence of all our Island,
Ye star'd upon her, as ye had seene a monster

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Was I so foolish; I confesse Eumenes,
I never saw before so brave an outside
But did I kneele so long

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Till they laught at ye,
And when you spoke, I am asham'd to tell ye
What 'twas my Lord; how farre from order;
Blesse me, is't possible the wild noise of a warre
And what she only teaches should possesse ye,
Knowledge to treat with her, and full discretion
Being at flood still in ye, and in peace,
And manly conversation smooth and civill,
Where gracefulnesse and glory twyn together
Thrust your selfe out an exile?
Doe you know sir, what state she carries?
What great obedience waits at her backe continually?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: She ne're commanded
A hundred thousand men, as I have done,
Nor ne're won battell; Say I would have kist her.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: There was a dainty offer too, a rare one.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why, she is a woman, is she not?

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: She is so.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why, very well; what was she made for then?
Is she not young and handsome bred to breed?
Doe not men kisse faire women? if they doe,
If lips be not unlawfull ware; Why a Princesse
Is got the same way that we get a begger,
Or I am cosen'd; and the selfe-same way
Shee must be handled e're she get another,
That's rudenesse is it not?

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: To her 'tis held so, & rudnes in that high degree.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: 'Tis reason,
But I will be more punctuall; pray what thought she?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Her thoughts were mercifull, but she laught at ye,
Pittying the poorenesse of your complement,
And so she left ye, good sir shape your selfe
To understand the place, and noble persons
You live with now.

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: Let not those great deserts
The King hath layd up of ye, and the people,
Be blasted with ill bearing.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: The whole name of souldier, then will suffer,

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Shee's a sweet one.
And good sirs leave your exhortations
They come untimely to me, I have braines
That beate above your reaches: Shee's a Princesse,
That's all: I have killed a King, that's greater.
Come let's to dinner, if the Wine be good,
You shall perceive strange wisdome in my blood.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Well, would thou wert i'the wars again
Old Memnon, there thou wouldst talke toth' purpose,
And the proudest of all these Court Camelions
Would be glad to find it sense too: plague of this
Dead peace, this bastard breeding lowzie lazie idlenesse,
Now we must learne to pipe, and pick our livings
Out of old rotten ends: these twenty five yeares
I have serv'd my Countrie, lost my youth and bloud,
Expos'd my life to dangers more then dayes.
Yet let me tell my wants, I know their answers,
The King is bound to right me, they good people
Have but from hand to mouth, looke to your wives
Your yong trim wives, your high-day wives, your march-paines,
For if the souldiers find not recompence,
As yet there's none a hatching; I beleeve
You men of wars, the men of wars will nick ye,
For sterve nor beg they must not, my small meanes
Are gone in fumo: here to raise a better
Unlesse it be with lying, or dog flattering,
At which our Nations excellent; observing dog-dayes,
When this good Lady broyles, and would be basted
By that good Lord or such like morall learnings,
Is here impossible; Well, I will rub among 'em
If any thing for honestie be gotten,
thou't be but bread and cheese I can be satisfied,
If otherwise the wind blow, stiffe as I am
Yet I shall learne to shuffle: There's an old Lasse
That shall be namelesse yet alive, my last hope,
Has often got me my pocket full of crownes
If all faile, Jack-Dawes, are you alive still?
Then I see the coast cleare, when fooles and boyes can prosper.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Brave Lievtenant

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Haile to the man of worship.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: You are fine sirs,
Most passing fine at all points.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: As ye see sir,
Home-bred and handsome, we cut not out our clothes sir
At halfe sword as your Taylors doe, and pinck 'em
With Pikes and Partizans, we live retir'd sir
Gentlemen like, and jealous of our honours.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Very fine Foole, and fine Boy, Peace playes with you
As the wind playes with feathers, dances ye
You grind with all gusts gallants.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: We can bounce sir,
When you Soldados bend i'th' hams, and frisk too.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: When twenty of your trip-coats turn their tippets,
And your cold sallets without salt or vineger
By wambling in your stomacks, hemp and hobnailes
Will beare no price now, hanging and old harneis
Are like to over-run us.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Whores and hot houses.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Surgeons and Sirenges ring out your sance-bells.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Your Jubile, your Jubile.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Proh Deum.
How our St. Georges will bestride the Dragons
The red and ramping Dragons.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Advanc't foole.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: But then the sting i'th' taile boy.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Tanto melior.
For so much the more danger, the more honour.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: You'r very pleasant with our occupation Gent.
Which very like amongst these fierie Serpents
May light upon a Blind-worme of your blood,
A Mother or a Sister.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Mine's past saddle
You should be sure of her else: but say Sir Huon
Now the Drums doubbes, & the sticks turn'd bed-staves,
All the old Foxes hunted to their holes,
The Iron age return'd to Eribus,
And Honorificabilitudinitatibus
Thrust out o'th' Kingdome by the head and shoulders,
What trade doe you meane to follow.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That's a question.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Yes and a learned question if ye marke it,
Consider and say on.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Fooling as thou dost, that's the best trade I take it.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Take it strait then
For feare your fellowes be before ye, harke ye Lievtenant
Foolings the thing, the thing worth all your fightings,
When all's done ye must foole sir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Well, I must then.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: But doe you know what fooling is; true fooling
The circumstances that belong unto it,
For every idle knave that showes his teeth
Wants and would live can Juggle tumble, fiddle,
Make a dog face, or can abuse his fellow,
Is not a foole at first dash, you shall find sir
Strange turnings in this trade; to foole is nothing
As fooling has bin but to foole the faire way,
The new way, as the best men foole their friends,
For all men get by fooling meerely fooling,
Desert does nothing valiant, wise, vertuous,
Are things that walke by without bread or breeches,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I partly credit that.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Fine wits, fine wits sir,
There's the young Boy, he does well in his way too,
He could not live else in his Masters absence;
He tyes a Ladyes garters so, so, pretily,
Say his hand slip, but say so.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Why let it slip then.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: 'Tis ten to one the body shall come after,
And he that workes deserves his wages.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That's true.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Hee riddles finely to a waiting Gentlewoman
Expounds dreames like a Prophet, dreames himselfe too,
And wishes all dreames true; they cry Amen,
And there's a Memorandum: he can sing too
Bawdy enough to please old Ladies: he lies rarely,
Pawnes ye a sute of clothes at all points, fully,
Can pick a pocket if ye please, or casket;
Lisps when he lists to catch a Chambermaid,
And calls his Hostesse mother, these are things now,
If a man meane to live, to fight and swagger,
Beaten about the Eares with bawling sheepskins,
Cut to the soule for Summer: here an arme lost,
And there a leg; his honourable head
Seal'd up in salves and searclothes, like a packet,
And so sent over to an Hospitall, stand there, charge there,
Sweare there, whore there, dead there,
And all this sport for cheese, and chines of dog-flesh,
And money when two Wednesdayes meet together,
Where to be lowzie is a Gentleman,
And he that weares a cleane shirt has his
Shrowd on.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I'le be your scholler, come if I like fooling.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: You cannot choose but like it, fight you one day
I'le foole another, when your Surgeons paid,
And all your leakes stopt, see whose slops are heaviest,
I'le have a shilling for a can of wine,
When you shall have two Sergeants for a counter.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Come learn of us Lievtenant, hang your Iron up,
Wee'le find you cooler warrs.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Come let's together,
I'le see your tricks, and as I like 'em.â€” Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why was there not such women in the camp then
Prepar'd to make me know 'em.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: 'Twas no place sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: Why should they live in Tumults: they are creatures
Soft and of sober natures.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Cou'd not your wives,
Your mothers, or your sisters have been sent for
To exercise upon.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: We thanke your Lordship.

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: But doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I doe meane.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: What sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: To see her,
And see thee hang'd too, and thou anger'st me,
And thousands of your throats cut, get ye from me
Ye keepe a prating of your points of manners,
And fill my head with lowzie circumstances,
Better have Ballets in 't your courtly worships,
How to put off my hat, you how to turne me,
And you forsooth to blow my nose discreetly;
Let me alone, for I will love her, see her,
Talke to her, and mine owne way.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Shee's the Princesse.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why let her be the devill, I have spoke,
When Thunder durst not check me, I must love,
I know she was a thing kept for me.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: And I know sir,
Though she were born yours, yet your strange behaviour
And want.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thou liest.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: I doe not.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: I doe not lye sir,
I say you want faire language, nay 'tis certaine
You cannot say good morrow.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ye Dog-whelpes,
The proudest of your prating tongues.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Doe kill us,
Kill us for telling truth, for my part Generall
I would not live to see men make a may-game
Of him I have made a Master, kill us quickly,
Then ye may.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Doe what you list, draw your sword childishly
Upon your servants that are bound to tell ye
I am weary of my life.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.l: And all sir.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Goe to the Princesse make her sport, cry to her
I am the glorious man of warre.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Pray ye leave me,
I am sorry I was angry, I'le thinke better,
Pray no more words.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.p: We are gone sir. Exeunt Eume. & Captains.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: How came he hither, see for heavens sake wenches,
What faces, and what postures he puts on, Mem. walks aside full of strange gestures.
I doe not thinke he is perfect.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: If your love
Have not betrayd his little wits, he's well enough.
As well as he will be.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Marke how he Muses.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Has a Battalia now in's braines, he draws out now
Have at ye Harpers.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: See, see, there the fire failes.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Look what an Alphabet of faces he runs through,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: O love, loue, how amorously thou look'st
In an old rusty armour.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I'le away, for by my troth I feare him.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Feare the gods Madam,
And never care what man can doe, this fellow
With all his frights about him and his furies,
His larums and his Launces, Swords and Targets,
Nay case him up in armour Cap-a-pe,
Yet durst I undertake within two houres,
If he durst charge to give him such a shake
Should shake his valour off, and make his shankes too

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: For shame no more.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Hee muses still.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The Devill.
Why should this old dried timber chopt with thunder.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Old wood burnes quickest.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Out you would say Madam,
Give me a green stick that may hold me heat
And smoke me soundly too: a turnes, and sees ye.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: There's no avoiding now, have at ye. Memnon comes to her.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Lady,
The more I looke upon ye. Stays her.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The more you may sir.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Let him alone.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I would desire your patience
The more I say I looke, the more Stays her.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: My Fortune
'Tis very apt Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Women let my fortune
And me alone I wish ye, pray come this way
And stand you still there Ladie

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Leave the words Sir, and leap into the meaning

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Then againe.
I tell you I doe love ye

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No questions: pray no more questions.
I doe love you. Infinitely, why doe you smile.
Am I ridiculous

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am monstrous fearefull, no I joye you love me

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Joye on then and be proud on't, I doe love ye,
Stand still doe not trouble me you Women.
He loves you Ladie at whose feete has kneeld
Princes to beg their freedomes, he whose valour
Has over run whole Kingdomes

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: That makes me doubt Sir
'Twill over run me to

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: He whose Sword

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Talke not so big Sir, you will fright the Princesse.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha. Lucip. No forsooth

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I know ye have done wonders.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I have and will doe more and greater braver.
And for your beautie miracles, name that kingdome
And talke your choice:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Sir I am not ambitious

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ye shalbe, 'tis the child of glory: she that I love
Whom my desires shall magnifie time stories
And all the Empire of the Earth:

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I would faine aske him.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Prethee be quiet, he will beate us both els.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What will ye make me then Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will make thee
Stand still and hold thy peace, I have a heart Ladie

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ye were a monster els

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: A loving heart
A truly loving heart:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Alas how came it

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I would you had it in your hand sweet Ladie
To see the truth it beares ye:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Doe you give it.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: That was well thought upon:

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: 'Twill put him too't wench;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And you shall see I dare accept it Sir
Tak't in my hand and view it: if I finde it
A loving and a sweet heart as you call it
I am bound, I am

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No more Ile send it to ye
As I have honour in me you shall have it

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Hansomlye done Sir, and perfum'd by all meanes
The weathers warme Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: With all circumstance

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: A napkin wrought most curiouslie;

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Divinely

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Put in a goblet of pure gold

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yes in Iacynth
That she may see the spirits through

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Ye have greas'd him
For chewing love again in hast

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: If he should doe it

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If Heaven should fall we should have larkes, he doe

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: See how he thinkes upon't

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He will thinke these three yeares
Ere he prove such an asse, I lik't his offer
There was no other way to put him of els.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will doe it
Ladie expect my heart

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I doe Sir:

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Love it and so I leave ye. Ex. Mem.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Either he is starke mad
Or els I thinke he meanes it

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He must be starke mad
Or he will never doe it, 'tis vaine glory
And want of judgement that provokes this in him
Sleepe and societie cures all his heart
No no good Gentleman ther's more belongs too't
Hearts are at higher prizes, lets goe in
And there examine him a little better.
Shut all the doores behind for feare he follow
I hope I have lost a lover, and am glad on't. Exit. Lady.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: 'Tis but to die, dogs doe it, ducks with dabling,
Birds sing away their soules, and babyes sleep 'em,
Why doe I talke of that is treble vantage,
For in the other world she is bound to have me,
Her Princely word is past: my great desert too
Will draw her to come after presently
'Tis justice, and the gods must see it done too
Besides no Brother, Father, kindred there
Can hinder us, all languages are a like too
There love is everlasting, ever young
Free from diseases, ages, jealousies.
Bawdes, beldames, painters, purgers, die, 'tis nothing
Men drowne themselves for joye to draw in Juleps
When they are hot with wine, In dreames we doe it,
And many a handsome wench that loves the sport well
Gives up her soule so in her lovers bosome,
But I must be incisde first, cut and open'd
My heart and handsomelie taine from me, staie there
Dead once stay, let me thinke agen, who doe I know there
For els to wander up and downe unwaited on
And unregarded in my place and project
Is for a sowters soule, not an old Souldiers.
My brave old Regiments: I there it goes
That have bin killd before me, right,

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Is here, and I must trouble him.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Then those I have conquer'd
To make my traine full:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My Captaines then:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Sir I beseech ye

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: For to meete her there
Being a Princesse and a Kings sole Sister
With great accommodation must be cared for

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Weigh but the Souldiers povertie

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Mine owne troope first
For they shall die:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: How what's this

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Next:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Shall I speake lowder Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: A square Battalia:

sp.speaker: hi.
sp.l: You doe not thinke of us.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Their Armours guilded:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Good noble Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And round about such Engines
Shall make hell shake:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ye doe not mock me

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: For Sir
I will be strange as brave

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ye may consider
You know we have serv'd you long enough

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No Souldier
That ever landed on the blest Elizium
Did or shall march, as I will

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Would ye would march Sir
Up to the King and get us

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: King nor Keiser
Shall equall me in that world

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: What a devill ayles he

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Next the rare beauties of those townes I fir'd

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I speake of mony Sir:

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ten thousand Coaches

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: O pounds Sir, pounds I beseech your Lordship
Let Coaches run out of your remembrance

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: In which the wanton Cupids; and the graces
Drawne with the Westerne winds kindling desires,
And then our Poets.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Then our pay

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: For Chilax when the triumph comes; the Princesse
Then for I will have a Heaven made

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Blesse your Lordship I
Stand still Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: So I doe and in it

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Death Sir
You talke you know not what

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Such rare devises:
Make me I say a Heaven

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I say so too Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: For here shall run a Constellation

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And there a pissing Conduit

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: With wine Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: A Sun there in his hight, there such a planet

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: But wher's our mony where runs that

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Money
Money ant like your Lordship

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why all the carriage, shall come behind the stuff
Rich hangings, treasure
Or say we have none

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I may say so truly
For hang me if I have a groat: I have serv'd well
And like an honest man: I see no reason

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thou must needs die good Chilax

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Very well Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will have honest, valiant soules about me
I cannot misse thee

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Dye?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yes die, and Pelius
Eumenes and Polibius: I shall thinke
Of more within these two howres

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Die Sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I Sir
And ye shall die

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: When I beseech your Lordship

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: To morrow see ye doe die

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A short warning,
Troth Sir I am ill prepar'd

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I die my selfe then
Beside ther's reason

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I pray thee tell me
For thou art a great dreamer

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I can dreame Sir
If I eate well and sleep well

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Was it never
By dreame or apparition open'd to thee?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Hees mad

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: What the other world was, or Elizium?
Didst never travell in thy sleepe?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: To Tauernes
When I was drunke ore night: or to a wench
Ther's an Elizium for yee, a young Ladie
Wrapt round about ye like a snake: is that it?
Or if that strange Elizium that you talke of
Be where the Devill is, I have dream't of him
And that I have had him by the hornes, and rid him
He trotts the Dagger out 'oth sheath

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Elizium,
The blessed fields, man

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I know no fields blessed, but those I have gain'd by
I have dreamp't I have bin in Heaven too

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: There, handle that place; that's Elizium

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Brave singing, and brave dancing
And rare things

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: All full of flowers

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And Pot hearbes

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Bowers for lovers
And everlasting ages of delight

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I slept not so far

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Meet me on those bancks
Some two dayes hence

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: In dreame Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No in death Sir
And there I muster all, and pay the Souldier
Away, no more, no more

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: God keepe your Lordship
This is fine dancing for us

sp.speaker: Siphax.
sp.l: Wher's the Generall

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ther's the old signe of Memnon, where the soule is
You may goe looke as I have

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: What's the matter

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Why question him and see; he talkes of Devills
Hells, Heavens, Princes, powers, and Potentates,
You must to'th pot too

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.p: Do you know Elizium a tale he talkes the wild goose chase of

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Elizium? I have red of such a place.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Then get he to him
Ye are as fine company as can be fitted. Exit Chilax.
Your worships fairelie mett

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Mercy upon us,
What ailes this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Provision

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: How his head workes.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Betweene two ribbes
If he cut short or mangle me; Ile take him
And twirle his neck about

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Now Gods defend us

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: In a pure cup transparant with a writing
To signifie

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I never knew him thus
Sure is bewitcht, or poysond;

sp.speaker: Mem,
sp.l: Whos's there

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Come hither Siphax

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Yes; how does your Lordship

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Well God a mercy Souldier, very well
But prithee tell me

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Any thing I can Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: What durst thou doe to gaine the rarest beautie
The World has

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: That the world has? 'tis worth doing

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Is it so? but what doing beares it?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Why any thing, all dangers it appeares to

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Name some of those things; doe

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I would undertake Sir
A voyage round about the World

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Short Siphax,
A merchant does it to spice potts of ale

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I woo'd swim in armour

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Short still: a poore Jade
Loden will take a streame and stem it strongly
To leap a Mare

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: The plague I durst

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Still shorter
Ile cure it with an Onyon

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Surfetts

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Short still
They are often Physicks for our healths and help us.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I woo'd stand a breach

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thine honour bids thee Souldier
'Tis shame to find a second cause

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I durst Sir
Fight with the fellest Monster

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: That's the poorest,
Man was ordained their Master; durst ye die Sir?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: How? die my Lord!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Die Siphax: take thy sword
And come by that doore to her; ther's a prize
To buy a lustie love at

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I am well content Sir
To proove no purchaser

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Away thou world worme,
Thou win a matchles beautie?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: 'Tis to loos't Sir
For being dead wher's the reward I reach at,
The love I labour for?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: There it begins foole
Thou art meerly cozend; for the loves wee now know
Are but the heats of half an houre; and hated
Desires stir'd up by nature to increase her
Licking of one another to a lust;
Course and base appetites earths meere inheritours
And heires of Idlenes and blood; Pure Love
That that the soule affects and cannot purchase
While she is loden with our flesh, that love Sir
Which is the price of honour dwells not here,
Your Ladies eyes are lamplesse to that vertue,
That beautie smiles not on a cheeke washt over,
Nor sents the sweets of Ambers; below, Siphax
Below us, in the other Word, Elizium,
Wher's no more dying, no despairing, mourning,
Where all desires are full, deserts downe loden,
There Siphax, there, where loves are ever living,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Why doe we love in this World then?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: To preserve it,
The maker lost his worke els: but marke Siphax,
What issues that love beares.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Why Children Sir;
I never heard him talke thus; thus divinelie
And sensible before

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: It does so, Siphax,
Things like our selves, as sensuall vaine unvented
Bubles and breath of ayres, got with an itching
As blisters are; and bred, as much corruption
Flowes from their lives, sorrow conceives and shapes 'em
And oftentimes the deaths of those we love most
The breeders bring them to the World to curse 'em,
Crying they weepe amongst us like young Catts,
Cares and continuall crosses keeping with 'em,
They make time old to tend them and experience
An asse they alter so; they grow and goodlie
'Ere we can turne our thoughts, like dropps of water
They fall into the maine, and knowne no more;
This is the love of this world: I must tell thee
For thou art understanding

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: What you please Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And as a faithfull man
Nay I dare trust thee
I love the Princesse

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: There 'tis that has fired him
I knew he had some inspiration
But does she know it Sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yes marry does she
I have given my heart unto her

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: If ye love her

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Nay understand me, my heart taken from me
Out of my body man and so brought to her
How lik'st thou that braue offer? ther's the love
I told thee of; and after death the living;
She must in justice, come boye, ha?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Your heart Sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I, so by all meanes Siphax

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: He loves rost well
That eates the spitt

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And since thou art come thus fitlie
Ile doe it presentlie and thou shall carrie it
For thou canst tell a storie and discribe it
And I coniure thee Siphax by thy gentrie
Next by the glorious battells we have fought in
By all the dangers, wounds, heats, colds, distresses,
Thy love next and obedience, nay thy life

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: But one thing first Sir, if she pleas'd to grant it
Could ye not love her here and live, consider

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha? yes I thinke I could

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: 'Twoul'd be far neerer
Besides the sweets here, would induce the last love
And linck it in

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thou sayest right, but our ranckes heere
And bloods are barrs between us, she must stand off too
As I perceive she does

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Desert and dutie
Makes even all Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Then the King, though I
Have merited as much as man can; must not let her,
So many Princes covetous of beautie;
I woo'd with all my heart but 'tis impossible

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Why say she marry after

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No she dare not
The Gods dare not doe ill: come

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Doe you meane it

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Lend me thy knife, and helpe me of

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: For heav'n sake
Be not so stupid mad deare Generall.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Dispatch, I say.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: As ye love that ye looke for
Heaven and the blessed life.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Hell take thee Coxcombe,
Why dost thou keepe me from it; thy knife, I say.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Doe but this one thing, on my knees I beg it,
Stay but two houres till I returne againe,
For I will to her, tell her all your merits,
Your most unvalu'd love, and last your danger;
If shee relent, then live still, and live loving,
Happy, and high in favour: if she frowne;

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Shall I be sure to know it.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: As I live Sir,
My quick returne shall either bring ye fortune,
Or leave you to your owne fate.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Two houres?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Let it be kept, away, I will expect it. Exeunt Memnon Siphax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: You dainty wits two, an ye to a Cater,
To cheat him of a dinner.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Ten at Court sir
Are few enough, they are as wise as we are.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Hang ye, I'le eat at any time: and any where
I never make that part of want, preach to me
What ye can doe, and when ye list.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Your patience,
'Tis a hard day at Court, a fish day.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: So it seemes sir,
The finns grow out of thy face.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: And to purchase
This day the company of one deare Custard,
Or a messe of Rice ap Thomas, needs a maine wit;
Beefe we can beare before us linde with Brewes
And tubs of Porke; vociferating Veales,
And tongues that ne're told lye yet.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Line thy mouth with 'em

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Thou hast need, and great need,
For these finny fish-dayes,
The Officers understandings are so flegmatick,
They cannot apprehend us.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That's great pitty,
For you deserve it, and being apprehended
The whip to boot; Boy what doe you so neare me,
I dare not trust your touch boy.

div.stage: Enter Stremon and his Boy Ed. Hor.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: As I am vertuous
What, theeves among our selves?

sp.speaker: Chy.
sp.l: Stremon.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Lievtenant.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Welcome ashore, ashore.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: What Monsieur, Musicke?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: My fine Foole.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Fellow Cracke, why what a consort
Are we now blest withall?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Fooling and fidling
Nay and we live not now boyes; what new songs sirra.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: A thousand man, a thousand.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Itching ayres
Alluding to the old sport.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Of all sizes.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: And how does small Tym Treble here; the heart on't.

sp.speaker: Boy. 2.
sp.l: To doe you service.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: O Tym the times, the times Tym.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: How does the Generall,
And next what moneys stirring?

sp.speaker: Chy.
sp.l: For the Generall
Is here, but such a Generall
The times chang'd Stremon,
He was the liberall Generall, and the loving,
The feeder of a Souldier, and the father,
But now become the stupid'st.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Why, what ailes he.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Nay, if a horse knew, and his head's big enough
I'le hang for't; did'st thou ever see a dog
Run mad o'th' tooth-ache, such another toy
Is he now so, a glotes and grins, and bites.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: Why hang him quickly,
And then he cannot hurt folkes.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: One houre raving,
Another smiling, not a word the third houre,
I tell thee Stremon has a stirring soule,
What ever it attempts or labours at
Would weare out twenty bodies in another.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: I'le keep it out of me, for mine's but buckeram,
Hee would bownce that out in two houres.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Then he talkes
The strangest and the maddest stuffe from reason,
Or any thing ye offer; stand thou there,
I'le show thee how he is, for I'le play Memnon
The strangest Generall that ere thou heardst of Stremon.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Goe presently and find me
A black horse with a blew taile; bid the blank Cornet
Charge through the Sea, and sinke the Navy: softly,
Our soules are things not to be waken'd in us
With larums, and lowd bawlings, for in Elizium
Stilnesse and quietnesse, and sweetnesse, sirra,
I will have, for it much concernes mine honour,
Such a strong reputation for my welcome
As all the world shall say: for in the forefront
So many on white Unicornes, next them
My gentlemen, my Cavaliers and Captaines,
Ten deep and trapt with tenter-hookes to take hold
Of all occasions: for Friday cannot fish out
The end I aime at; tell me of Diocles,
And what he dare doe, dare he meet me naked
Thunder in this hand, in his left? Foole?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Foole, I would have thee fly i'th' ayre fly swiftly
To that place where the Sun sets, there deliver.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Deliver? what sir?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: This sir, this ye slave sir, All laugh.
Death ye rude rogues, ye Scarrubbs.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Hold for Heav'ns sake Lievtenant, sweet Lievtenant.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I have done sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You have wrung his neck off.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: No Boy, 'tis the nature
Of this strange passion when't hits to hale people
Along by th'haire, to kick 'em, breake their heads:

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Do ye call this Acting, was your part to beat me.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Yes, I must act all that he does.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Plague act yee,
I'le act no more.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: 'Tis but to shew man.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Then man
Hee should have shew'd it only, and not done it,
I am sure he beat me beyond Action,
Gowts a your heavy fist.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ile have thee to him,
Thou hast a fine wit, fine foole, and canst play rarely.
Hele hug thee, boy, and stroke thee,

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Ile to the stockes first,
'Ere I be strokt thus.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: But how came he Chilax?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I know not that,

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Ile to him

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: He loves thee well,
And much delights to here thee sing; much taken
He has bin with thy battell songs.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: If Musique,
Can find his madnes; Ile so fiddle a him,
That out it shall by'th shoulders,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: My fine fidler,
Hele firke you and ye take not heed too: t'will be rare sport
To see his owne trade triumph over him;
His Lute lac'd to his head, for creeping hedges;
For mony ther's none stirring; try good Stremon
Now what your silver sound can doe; our voices
Are but vaine Ecchoes,

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Something shall be done
Shall make him understand all; lets to'th Taverne,
I have some few Crownes left yet: my whistle wet once
Ile pipe him such a Paven-

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Hold thy head up,
Ie cure it with a quart of wine; Come Coxcombe;
Come boye take heed of napkins.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Youl'd no more acting?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: No more Chicken;

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Goe then.

div.stage: Enter Siphax at one Dore, and a Gentleman at another.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: God save you sir; pray how might I see the Princess

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why very fitly sir shees even now ready,
To wake out this way into'th parke; stand there,
Ye cannot misse her sight, sir,

sp.speaker: Siphax.
sp.l: I much thanke ye.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Lets have a care, for Ile assure ye wenches
I woo'd not meet him willingly agen;
For though I doe not feare him, yet his fashion
I wood not be acquainted much wit'h.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Gentle Ladie,
Ye need not feare the walkes are viewed and emptie,
But my thinkes Madam this kind heart of hisâ€”

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Is slow a coming.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Keepe me ye blest Angells,
What killing power is this?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why dost thou looke for't?
Dost thinke he spoke in earnest?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: My thinkes Madam,
A Gentleman should keepe his word; and to a Ladie
A Ladie of your excellencies;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Out foole!
Send me his heart? what should we doe wo't? dance it?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Drie it and drinke it for the wormes.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Whos's that?
What man stands there?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A Gentleman,
Which I beseech your grace to honour so much,
As know him for your servants brother.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Siphax?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: The same an't please your grace; what does he here?
Upon what busines and I ignorant?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hee's growne a handsome Gentleman; good Siphax
Yat wel-come from the warres; woo'd ye with us sir?
Pray speake your will: a blushes, be not feareful,
I can assure ye for your Sisters sake sir,
Ther's my hand on it.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Doe you heare Sir?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Sure these Souldiers,
Are all growne senseles,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Doe ye know where ye are sir?

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Tongue-tyde,
He lookes not well too, by my life, I thinke;

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Speake, for shame speake.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: A man woo'd speakeâ€”

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: These Souldiers,
Are all dumb Saints: Consider and take time sir,
Lets forward wenches come, his pallats downe.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Dare these men charge it'h face of fire and bullets?
And hang there heads downe at a handsome Woman?
Good master Mars that 's a soule fault.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Fye beast,
No more my brother.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: Sister, honoured Sister,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Dishonoured foole,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I doe confesse,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Fye on thee,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: But stay till I deliver,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Let me goe,
I am a shame to owne thee,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Fare ye well then,
Ye must nere see me more,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Why stay deare Siphax,
My anger's past; I will heare ye speake

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: O Sister,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Out with it Man,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: O I have drunke my mischiefe,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ha? what?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: My destruction.
In at mine eyes I have drunke it; O the Princess,
The rare sweet Princess!

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: How foole? the rare Princess?
Was it the Princess that thou sed'st?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: The Princess,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Thou doest not love her sure, thou darst not.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Yes by heaven,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Yes by Heaven? I know thou darst not,
The Princess? 'tis thy life the knowledge of it,
Presumption that will draw into it all thy kinred,
And leave 'em slaves and succourles; the Princess?
Why shee's a sacred thing to see and worship,
Fixt from us as the Sun is high and glorious,
To be ador'd not doated on; desire things possible,
Thou foolish young man, nourish not a hope,
Will haile thy heart out.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: 'Tis my destinie,
And I know both disgrace and death will quit it,
If it be knowne

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Pursue it not then Syphax
Get thee good wholesome thoughts may nourish thee.
Goe home and pray

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I cannot

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Sleep then Syphax.
And dreame away thy doting.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I must have her
Or you no more your brother; worke Cleanthe,
Worke, and worke speedilie, or I shall die wench.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Dye then, I dare forget; farewell

sp.speaker: Syp.
sp.l: Farewell Sister.
Farewell for ever, see me buried.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Stay.
Pray stay? hee's all my brothers: no way Siphax.
No other Woman,

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: None, none, shee or sincking.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Goe and hope well, my life Ile venture for thee
And all my art, a Woman may worke miracles;
No more, pray heartily against my fortunes,
For much I feare a maine one.

sp.speaker: Syphax.
sp.l: I shall doe it. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter a Priest of Venus and a Boye.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Find him by any meanes; and good child tell him
He has forgot his old friend, give him this,
And say this night without excuse or busines
As ever he may find a friend, come to me,
He knowes the way and how, begon.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I gallop. Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I have bin looking you;

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: The faire Cleanthe,
What may your busines be?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O holy Mother
Such busines of such strange waite, now or never.
As ye have loved me, as ye doe or may doe,
When I shall find a fit time.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: If by my meanes
Your busines may be fitted; ye know me,
And how I am tyed unto you; be bold daughter
To build your best hopes,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O but 'tis a strange one
Stuck with as many dangers-

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Ther's the working,
Small things performe themselves and give no pleasures;
Be confident through death Ile serve.

sp.speaker: Clean
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Fye no corruption

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Take it; 'tis yours,
Be not so spiced, 'tis good gold
And goodnes is no gall to'th conscience,
I know you have wayes to vent it: ye may hold it

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Ile keep it for ye; when?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: To morrow morning
Ile visit ye agen; and when occasion
Offers it selfe-

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Instruct me, and have at ye-

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Farewell till then; be sure.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: As your owne thoughts, Ladie.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: 'Tis a maine worke and full of feare.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Fooles only Exit Cle.
Make their effects seeme fearefull: farewell daughter.
This gold was well got for my old tuff Souldier
Now I shall be his sweet agen; what busines
Is this she has a foote? some lustie lover
Beyond her line, the young wench would faine piddle
A little to revive her, must be thought of,
'Tis even so; she must have it; but how by my meanes
A devill can she drive it? I that wait still
Before the Goddesse giving Oracle
How can I profit her? 'tis her owne project,
And if she cast it false her owne fault be it. Exit. Priest.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Why this is utter madnes

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Thus it is Sir

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Only the Princesse sight?

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: All we can judge at;

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: This must be loo'kt to timelie.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Yes and wiselie;

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: He do's not offer at his life

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: not yet sir
That we can heare of

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Noble Gentlemen;
Let me entreat your watches over him.
Ye cannot doe a worthier worke.

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: We came Sir
Provided for that service?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Where is Chilax?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: A little busie Sir?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Is the foole and boye here.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: They are Sir,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Let 'em be still so; and as they find his humors

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Now ye may behold him

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Stand close and worke no noyse;
By his eyes now, Gentlemen,
I guesse him full of anger

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Be not seene there

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: The houre's past long agoe, hees false and fearefull,
Coward goe with thy catine soule, thou our dog.
Thou cold clod, wilde fire warme thee, monstrous fearful,
I know the slave shakes but to thinke on't.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Whos's that?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: I know not Sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: But I shall catch yee rascall,
Your mangie soule is not immortall here Sir,
Ye must die, and we must meet; we must, maggot,
Be sure we must, for not a nooke of hell,
Not the most horrid pit shall harbour thee.
The Devills taile shall hide thee, but Ile have thee,
And how Ile use thee, whips and firebrands
Tosting thy taile against a flame of wilde fire,
And basting it with brimstone, shall be nothing,
Nothing at all; Ile reach ye to be treacherous;
Was never slave so swing'd since hell was hell
As I will swinge thy slaves soule: and be sure on't.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Is this imagination, or some circumstance
For 'tis extreame strange.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: So is all he does Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Till then Ile leave ye? whos's there? where's the Surgeon.
Demagoras. Enter Surgion.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My Lord,

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Bring the Surgeon.
And waite you too. Enter Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: What wood ye with a Surgeon

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Things mustring in his head: pray marke

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Come hither.
Have you brought your Instruments.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: They are within Sir,

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Put to the doores a while there; ye can incise
To a haires bredth without defacing;

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And take out fairely from the flesh;

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: The least thing.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Well, come hither then; take off my doublet,
for looke ye Surgeon, I must have ye cut
My Heart out here, and handsomly: Nay, stare not,
Nor doe not start; I'le cut your throat else Surgeon,
Come sweare to doe it.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Good sirâ€”

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Sirra, hold him,
I'le have but one blow at his head.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I'le doe it,
Why what should we doe living after you sir?
Wee'le die before if yee please.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No, No.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Living? hang living,
Is there ne're a Cat hole where I may creep through?
Woo'd I were in the Indies.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Sweare then, and after my death presently
To kill your selves and follow, as ye are honest,
As ye have faiths and loves to me.

sp.speaker: Dema.
sp.l: Wee'l doe it.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Pray doe not stir yet, we are neare enough
To run between all dangers.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Here I am sir;
Come looke upon me, view the best way boldly,
Feare nothing but cut home; if your hand shake sirra,
Or any way deface my heart i'th' cutting,
Make the least scratch upon it, but draw it whole,
Excellent faire, shewing at all points, Surgeon,
The honour and the valour of the owner,
Mixt with the most immaculate love I send it,
Looke too't, I'le slice thee to the soule.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Ne're feare sir,
I'le doe it daintily; would I were out once.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will not have ye smile sirra when ye do it,
As though ye cut a Ladies corne; tis scurvie;
Doe me it as thou dost thy praiers, seriously.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I'le doe it in a dump sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: In a dog sir,
I'le have no dumps, nor dumplins: fetch your tooles,
And then I'le tell ye more.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: If I returne
To heare more I'le be hang'd for't.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Quick, quick.

sp.speaker: Dema.
sp.l: Yes sir,
With all the heeles we have, Exeunt Surgeon. Demagoras.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Yet stand.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: Hee'le doe it.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: He cannot and we here.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why when ye rascalls,
Ye dull slaves: will ye come sir? Surgeon, Serring,
Dogleach, shall I come fetch ye?

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: Now I'le to him,
God save ye honour'd brother

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My deare Polidor,
Welcome from travell welcome; and how doe ye?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Well sir, would you were so.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I am, I thanke ye,
You are a better'd man much, I the same still,
An old rude Souldier, sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Pray be plaine brother,
And tell me but the meaning of this vision,
For to me it appeares no more: so farre
From common course and reason.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thanke thee Fortune,
At length I have found the man: the man must do it,
The man in honour bound.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: To doe what?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Harke, for I will blesse ye with the circumstance
Of that weak shaddow that appear'd.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Speake on sir. Walkes with him.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: It is no storie for all eares.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The Princesse?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Peace and heare all: how:

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Sure 'tis dangerous
He starts so at it,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Your heart, doe ye know sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yes, pray thee be softer.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Me to doe it?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Only Reserv'd, and dedicated.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: For shame brother
Know, what, ye are, a man.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: None of your Athens
Good sweet sir, no Philosophy, thou feel'st not
The honourable end, foole.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I am sure I feele
The shame & scorn that follows; have ye serv'd thus long
The glory of your Country, in your Conquests,
The envy of your neighbours, in your vertues,
Rul'd Armies of your owne, given Lawes to Nations,
Belov'd and fear'd as far as Fame has travel'd,
Call'd the most fortunate and happy Memnon,
To loose all here at home, poorely to loose it,
Poorely and pettishly, ridiculously
To fling away your fortune? where's your wisdome?
Where's that you govern'd others by, discretion?
Do's your Rule lastly hold upon your selfe? fie brother,
How are ye falne? get up into your honour
The top branch of your bravery, and from thence
Looke and lament how little Memnon seemes now.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Hum! tis well spoken; but do'st thou think, young scholler
The tongues of Angels from my happinesse
Could turne the end I aime at? no: they cannot;
This is no booke case brother: will ye doe it?
Use no more art, I am resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Ye may, sir
Command me to doe any thing that's honest,
And for your noble end: but this it carries.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ye shall not be so honour'd; live an Asse still,
And learne to spell for profit: goe, goe studie.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Ye must not hold him up so, he is lost then.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Get thee to schoole agen, and talke of turnips,
And find the naturall cause out, why a dog
Turnes thrice about e're he ly downe: there's learning.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Come, I will doe it now; 'tis brave, I find it,
And now allow the reason.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: O doe ye so sir,
Doe ye find it currant?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Yes, yes, excellent.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I told ye.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I was foolish: I have here too
The rarest way to find the truth out; hark ye,
Ye shall be rul'd by me.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will be: butâ€”

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: I reach it,
If the worst fall, have at the worst: wee'le both goe
But two dayes, and 'tis thus; ha?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: 'Twill doe well so

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then if not excellent, doe ye conceive it

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: 'Twill worke for certaine A bowle ready.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: O 'twill tickle her
And you shall know then by a line

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I like it
But let me not be fool'd againe

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Doubt nothing
You doe me wrong then, get ye in there privat
As I have taught ye; Basta

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Worke (Exit Memnon.)

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I will doe

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Have ye found the cause

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Yes, and the straingest, Gentlemen,
That ere I heard of, anon Ile tell ye; Stremon
Be you still neere him to affect his fancie
And keepe his thoughts off: Let the Foole and Boy
Stay him, they may doe some pleasure too; Eumenes
What if he had a wench, an handsome whore brought
Rarely drest up, and taught to state it?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Well Sir

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: His cause is meerly heat: and made beleeve
It were the Princesse mad for him,

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: I thinke
'Twere not amisse.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: And let him kisse her

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: What els?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: Ile be his bawde ant please you, young and holesome
I can assure ye he shall have

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Faith let him

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: A shall, I hope 'twill helpe him, walke a little
Ile tell you how his case stands, and my project
In which you must be mourners, but by all meanes
Stir not you from him: Stremon.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.p: On our Lives Sir Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: O y'ar a pretious Man; two daies in towne
And neuer see your old friend?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Prithe pardon me

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: And in my conscience if I had not sent

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: No more I would a come; I must

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I find ye
God a mercy want ye never care for me
But when your slops are emptie

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Nere feare that wench
Shall find good currant coyne still; is this the old house?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Have ye forgot it?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And the dore still standing
That goes into the Temple?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Still.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: The Robes to,
That I was wount to shift in here?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: All here still.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: O ye tuff rogue what troubles have I trotted through?
What feares and frights, every poore mouse a monster
That I heard stir, and every stick I trod on
A sharp sting to my conscience

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Las poore conscience,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And all to liquor thy old bootes wench

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Out beast!

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: To new carine thy carkas, that's the truth on't
How does thy keele? does it need nayling? a tother
When all thy linnen's up: and a more yare?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Fye Fye Sir

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Nere stem'd the straights?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: How you talke?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I am old wench,
And talking to an old Man is like a stomacher
It keepes his blood warme

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: But; pray tell me

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Any thing

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Where did the boy meet with ye, at a wench sure,
At one end of a wench, a Cup of wine sure

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Thou know'st I am too honest

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: That's your fault
And that the Surgeon knowes

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Then farewell
I will not faile ye soone

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: Ye shall staye Supper
I have sworne ye shall, by this ye shall

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I will wench,
But after Supper for an houre, my busines

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: And but an houre

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: No by this kisse, that ended
I will returne and all night in thine Armes wench

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: No more, Ile take your meaning; come 'tis Supper time

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Thou art not well

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Your grace sees more a great deale
Then I feele (yet I lye) o brother.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Marke her,
Is not the quicknes of her ey consumed, wench?
The livelye red and white?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Nay she is much alter'd
That on my understanding, all her sleep's Ladie
Which were as sound and sweet

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Pray doe not force me
Good Madam where I am not, to be ill,
Conceit's a double sicknes; on my faith your highnes
Is meere mistaken in me A Dead March within of Drum and Sagbutts

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am glad on't
Yet this I have ever noted when thou wast thus
It still forerun some strange event: my Sister
Died when thou wast thus last: harke harke ho,
What mournefull noyse is this comes creeping forward,
Still it growes neerer, neerer, do ye heare it?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: It seemes some Souldiers funerall: see it enters

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: What may it meane?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The Gods keep ye faire Calis

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: This man can speake, and well; a stands and views us
Woo'd I were nere worse look't upon: how humbly
His eyes are cast now to the earth: pray marke him
And marke how rarely he has ranckt his troubles:
See now a weepes, they all weep; a sweeter sorrow
I never look't upon nor one that braver
Became his griefe; your will with us.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Great Ladie Plucks out the Cup.
Excellent beauty

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He speakes handsomelie
What a rare rhetorician his greif plaies,
That stop was admirable

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: See see thou Princesse
Thou great commander of all hearts

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I have found it,
Oh how my soule shakes:

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: See, see the noble hart
Of him that was the noblest: see and glory
Like the proud God himselfe in what thou hast purchas'd
Behold the heart of Memnon: does it start ye?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Good gods, what has his wildenes done?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Looke boldlie
You boldlie sed you durst looke wretched woman,
Nay flie not back faire follie, 'tis too late now
Vertue and blooming honour bleed to death here,
Take it the Legacie of Love bequeath'd ye,
Of cruell Love, a cruell Legacie;
What was the will that wrought it? then can ye weepe?
Imbalme it in your truest teares?
If Women can weepe a truth, or ever sorrow sunck yet
Into the soule of your sex, for 'tis a Jewell
The Worlds worth cannot weigh downe,
Take it Ladie; And with it all (I dare not curse) my sorrowes
And may they turne to Serpents.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: How she lookes
Still upon him: see now a teare steales from her

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: But still she keepes her ey firme

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Next read this,
But since I see your spirit somewhat troubled
Ile doe it for ye

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.p: Still she eyes him mainlie

lg.l: Goe happy heart for thou shalt ly
Intomb'd in her for whom I dy
Example of her cruelty.
Tell her if she chance to chide
Me for slownes in her pride
That it was for her I died.
If a teare escape her eye
'Tis not for my memory.
But thy rights of obsequy
The Altar was my loving brest
My heart the sacrificed beast
And I was my selfe the Preist
Your body was the sacred shrine
Your cruell mind the power divine
Pleas'd with hearts of men not kine

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Now it poures downe

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I like it rarelie Ladie

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: How greedily she swallowes up his language?

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: Her eye inhabits on him

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Cruell Ladie,
Great as your beautie scornefull; had your power
But equall poise on all hearts; all hearts perish't;
But Cupid has more shafts then one more flames too
And now he must be open ey'd, 'tis Justice:
Live to injoye your longing; live and laugh at
The losses and the miseries we suffer;
Live to be spoken when your crueltie
Has cut of all the vertue from this Kingdome
Turned honour into earth, and faithfull service

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I sweare his angers excellent

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Truth and most tried love
Into disdaine and downefall,

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Still more pleasing,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Live then I say famous for civill slaughters,
Live and lay out your triumphs, guild your glories
Live and be spoken this is she this Ladie,
This goodly Ladie, yet most killing beautie;
This with the two edg'd eyes, the heart for hardnes
Out doing rockes; and coldnes, rockes of Christall
This with the swelling soule, more coye of Courtship
Then the proud sea is when the shores embrace him
Live till the mothers find ye; read your story
And sowe their barren curses on your beauty,
Till those that have enjoy'd their loves despise ye,
Till Virgins pray against ye, old age find ye
And even as wasted coales glow in their dying
So may the Gods reward ye in your ashes:
But y'ar the Sister of my King; more prophesies
Els I should utter of ye true loves and loyall
Blesse themselves ever from ye: so I leave ye

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Prithee be angry still young man: good faire Sir
Chide me againe, what wood this man doe pleas'd,
That in his passions can bewitch soules stay,

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Upon my life she loves him

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Pray stay

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: No

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I doe command ye

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: No, ye cannot Ladie
I have a spell against yee, Faith and Reason,
Yee are to weak to reach me: I have a heart too,
But not for hawkes meat Ladie

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Even for Charity
Leave me not thus aflicted: you can teach me

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: How can you Preach that Charitie to others
That in your owne soule are an Athiest
Beleeving neither power nor feare: I trouble ye,
The Gods be good unto ye.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Ladie, She Swounes

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O royall Madam, Gentlemen for heav'n sake, They come back.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Give her fresh air she comes again: away sirs
And here stand close till we perceive the working

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Ye have undone all

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: So I feare

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: She loves ye

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: And then all hopes lost this way

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Peace she rises

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Now for my purpose Fortune

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Wher's the Gentleman

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Gone Madam

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why gone?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Has dispatch't his busines

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: A came to speake with me
A did,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A did not

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: For I had many questions

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: On my Faith Madam, he
Talk't a great while to ye

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Thou conceiv'st not.
He talk't not as he should doo; o my heart
Away with that sad sight; didst thou ere love me?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Why doe you make that question?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If thou didst
Run run wench, run: nay see how thou stir'st

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If 'twer for any thing to please thy selfe
Thou wood'st run to'th devill: but I am growne

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Fie Ladie

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I aske none of your fortunes, nor your loves
None of your bent desires I slack, ye are not
In love with all men, are ye? one for shame
You will leave your honour'd mistris? why doe ye stare so
What is that ye see about mee, tell me;
Lord what am I become? I am not wilde sure,
Heaven keepe that from me: o Cleanthe help me
Or I am suncke to death

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ye have offended and mightily, love is incenst against yee
And therefore take my Councell, to the Temple
For that's the speediest physick: before the Goddesse
Give your repentant prayers: aske her will
And from the Oracle attend your sentence
She is milde and mercifull

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: I will: o Venus
Even as thou lov'st thy selfe!

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Now for my fortune Exeunt Calis and Women.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: What shall I doe?

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: Why make your selfe

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: I dare not,
No Gentlemen, I dare not be a villaine
Though her bright beauty would entice an Angell
I will to'th King my last hope: get him a Woman
As we before concluded: and as ye passe
Give out the Spartans are in armes; and terrible
And let some letters to that end be fain'd too
And sent to you, some Poets too, to the Generall
And let me worke: be nere him still,

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: We will Sir

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Farwell: and pray for all: what 'ere I will ye
Doe it, and hope a faire end

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: The Gods speed ye. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Stremon Foole, Boy, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: He lies quiet

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Let him lye and as I told ye
Make ready for this shew: h'as divers times
Been calling upon Orpheus to appeare
And shew the joyes: now I wilbe that Orpheus,
And as I play and sing like beasts and trees
I woo'd have you shapt and enter: thou a Dog, foole,
I have sent about your sutes: the Boy a bush,
An Asse you, you a Lion

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: I a dog?
Ile fit you for a Dog. Bow wow

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: 'Tis excellent
Steale in and make no noise

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Bow wow

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Away rogue. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: Good sweet friend be not long

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Thou think'st each houre ten
Till I be ferreting

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: You know I love ye

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I will not be above an houre; let thy robe be readie
And the doore be kept Knock.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Who knocks there? Cleanthe knocks within.
Yet more busines?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Have ye more pensioners, the Princesse woman?
Nay then Ile stay a little, what games a foote now?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Now is the time

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A rancke bawde by this hand, too
She grinds a both sides: hey boyes

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: How your brother Siphax?
Loves he the Princesse?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Deadlie, and you know
He is a Gentleman descended noblie.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: But a ranck knave as ever pist

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: â—old Mother
Here's more gold and some jewells

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Here's no villany
I am glad I came to'th hearing

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Alas Daughter,
What would ye have me doe?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Hold off ye old whore;
Ther's more gold comming; all's mine, all

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Doe ye shrink now,
Did ye not promise faithfully and told me
Through any danger?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Any I can wade through

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ye shall, and easilie the sin not seene neither
Here's for a better stole and a new vaile mother
Come ye shall be my friend: if all hit

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Hang me
Ile make ye richer then the Goddesse.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Say then
I am yours, what must I doe?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I'th morning
But very early, will the Princesse visit
The Temple of the Goddesse, being troubled
With strange things that distract her: from the Oracle
(Being strongly too in love) she will demand
The Goddesse pleasure, and a Man to cure her,
That Oracle you give: describe my Brother
You know him perfectly.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I have seene him often

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And charge her take the next man she shall meet with
When she comes out; you understand me

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Which shalbe he attending; this is all
And easily without suspition ended,
Nor none dare disobey, 'tis Heaven that does it,
And who dares crosse it then, or once suspect it?
The venture is most easie.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I will doe it.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: As ye shall prosper;

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: As I shall prosper.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Take this too, and farewell; but first harke hither.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: What a young whores this to betray her mistris?
A thousand Cuckolds shall that husband be,
That marries thee, thou art so mischievous.
Ile put a spoke among your wheeles

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Be constant

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: 'Tis done

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.p: Ile doe no more at drop shot then Exit Chilax.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Farewell wench. Exeunt Priest and Cleanthe

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter a Servant and R. Bax, and Stremon at the doore.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: A stirs a stirs

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Let him, I am ready for him,
He shall not this day perish, if his passions
May bee fed with Musick; are they ready

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: All, all: see where he comes

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Ile be straight for him. Exit Stremon.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: How sad he lookes and sullen. Stand close.
Here are the Captaines: my feares past now.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Put case i'th other world
She doe not love me neither: I am old 'tis certaine

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: His spirit is a little quieter.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My blood lost and my limbes stif; my embraces
Like the cold stubborne baâ—kes â—hoaâ—ie and hearbes
My words worse: my fame only and atcheivements
