Which are my strength, my blood, my youth my fashion,
Must woe her, win her, wed her; that's but wind
And Women are not brought to bed with shadowes:
I doe her wrong, much wrong; she is young and blessed,
Sweet as the spring, and as his blossomes tender,
And I a nipping north wind, my head hung
With hailes, and frostie Isicles: are the soules so too
When they depart hence, lame and old, and love les?
No sure, 'tis ever youth there; Time and Death
Follow our flesh no more: and that forc'd opinion
That Spirits have no sexes, I beleive not
There must be love, there is love? what art thou.

lg.l: Orpheus, I am come from the deep's below,
To thee fond man the plagues of love to show:
To the faire fields where loves eternall dwell
Ther's none that came, but first they passe through hell:
Harke and beware unlesse thou hast loved ever,
Beloved againe, thou shalt see those joyes never.
Hark how they groane that dyed despairing,
O take heed thou:
Hark how they houle for over daring
All those were men.
They that be fooles, and dye for fame
They loose their name,
And they that bleed
Harke how they speed.
Now in cold frosts now scorching fires,
They sit and curse their lost desires:
Nor shall these soules be free from paines and feares,
Till Women wast them over in their teares.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: How should I know my passage is deni'de me
Or which of all the Devills dare

sp.speaker: Eumon.
sp.l: This Song
Was rarely formed to fit him.

sp.speaker: Orph.
sp.l: Charon o Charon
Thou wafter of the soules to blisse or bant

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Who calls the Fery man of Hell?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Come near
And say who lives in joye, and whom in feare.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Those that dye well; Eternall joy shall follow,
Those that dye ill; their owne soule saie shall swallow.

sp.speaker: Orph.
sp.l: Shall thy black Bark those guilty spirits stow
That kill themselves for love?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: O no no.
My cordage crackes when such great sins are neare
No winde blowes faire, nor I my selfe can steare

sp.speaker: Orph.
sp.l: What lovers passe and in Elizium raigne?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Those gentle loves that are belov'd againe.

sp.speaker: Orph.
sp.l: This Souldier Loves, and faine wood dye to win,
Shall he goe on?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: No 'tis too foule a sin
He must not come a boord: I dare not rowe,
Stormes of despaire and guilty blood will blowe.

sp.speaker: Orph.
sp.l: Shall time release him saye?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: No, no, no no.
Nor time nor death can alter us, nor prayer;
My boate is de and who then dare
But those appointed come aboord Live still,
And love by reason mortall not by will,

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: And when thy Mistris shall close up thine eyes

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Then come a boord and passe,

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Till when be wise

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Till when be wise.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: How still he sitts: I hope this Song has setled him

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: He bites his lipp, and rowles his fierce eyes yet
I feare for all this

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: Stremon still apply to him;

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Give me more roome then, sweetlie strike divinely
Such straines and old earth moves at

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: The power I have over both Beast and plant
Thou man alone feelst miserable want Music.
Strike your rare Spirits that attend my will,
And loose your savage wildnesse by my skill.
This Lion was a man of Warre that died,
As thou wouldst doe to guild her Ladies pride
This Dog a foole that hung himselfe for love:
This Ape with daily hugging of a glove,
Forgot to eat and died. This goodly tree,
An usher that still grew before his Ladie,
Wither'd at roote. This, for he could not wooe,
A grumbling Lawyer: This pyed Bird a page,
That melted out because he wanted age.
Still these lye houling on the stigian shore,
O love no more, o love no more.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: He steales off silently, as though he would sleep,
No more but all be nere him, feed his fancie
Good Stremon still; this may lock up his follie.
Yet Heaven knowes I must feare him; away softly.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Did I not doe most doggedly?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Most rarelie?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Hee's a brave man when shall we dog agen;

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Unty me first for Gods sake,

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Helpe the Boye; hee's in a wood poore child: good honny Stremon
Lets have a beare baiting; ye shall see me play.
The rarest for a single Dog: at head all;
And if I doe not win immortall glorie,
Play, Dog play Devill.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Peace for this time,

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Prithee.
Lets sing him a blacke Santis, then lets all howle,
In our owne beastly voices; tree keepe your time,
Untye there; bow, wow, wow.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: A way ye Asse, away,

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Why let us doe something,
To satisfie the Gentleman, hee's mad;
A Gentleman like humour and in fashion,
And must have men as mad about him.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Peace
And come in quicklie, 'tis ten to one els
Heel find a staffe to beat a dog; no more words,
Ile get ye all imployment; soft soft in all, Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: When camest thou over wench?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But now this evening.
And have bin ever since looking out Siphax,
ith' warres he would have lookt me: sure has gotten
Some other Mistris.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A thousand wench, a thousand
They are as common here as Caterpillers
Among the corne, they eat up all the Souldiers,

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Are they so hungry? yet by their leave Chilax,
Ile have a snatch too.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Dost thou love him still wench?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Why should I not? he had my Maiden head
And all my youth.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Thou art come the happiest
In the most blessed time, sweet wench the fittest,
If thou darst make thy fortune: by this light Cloe
And so Ile kiss thee: and if thou wilt but let me,
For 'tis well worth a kindnes.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: What shood I let ye?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Enjoye thy miniken

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Thou art still old Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Still still and ever shalbe: if, I say,
Thou wo't strike the stroke: I cannot doe much harme wench

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Nor much good

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Siphax shall be thy Husband,
Thy very Husband woman, thy foole thy Cuckold,
Or what thou wilt make him: I am over joy'd,
Ravisht cleane ravisht with this fortune; kiss me,
Or I shall loose my self,

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: My Husband sed ye?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Sed I? and will say Cloe; nay and doe it
And doe it home to; Peg thee as close to him
As birdes are with a pinne to one another;
I have it I can doe it: thou wants clothes too,
And heel be hanged unles he marry thee
Ere he maintaine thee: now he has Ladies Courtiers
More then his back can bend at? multitudes
We are taken up for threshers, will ye bite?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And let me-

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes and let ye-

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: What!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Why that ye wo't of.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: The turne the good turne?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Any turne the Roche turne;

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That's the right turne for that turnes up the bellie.
I cannot stay take your instructions
And something toward howshold, come, what ever
I shall advise ye follow it exactlie
And keep your times I point ye; for Ile tell ye
A strange way you must wade through.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Feare not me Sir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Come then and lets dispatch this modicum
For I have but an howre to stay, a short one
Besides more water for another mill
An old weake over shot I must provide for,
Ther's an old Nunnerie at hand.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: What's that

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A bawdie House.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: A pox consume it

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: If the stones ('tis built on)
Were but as brickle as the flesh lives in it,
Your curse came handsomlie: feare not, ther's Ladies,
And other good sad people: your pinkt Citizens
That thinke no shame to shake a sheet there: Come wench

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A Souldier and so fearefull?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Can ye blame me;
When such a waite lies on me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Fye upon ye
I tell ye, ye shall have her: have her safelie,
And for your wife with her owne will,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Good Sister-

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What a distrustfull man are you? to morrow,
To morrow morning-

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Is it possible?
Can there be such a happines?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Why hang me
If then ye be not married: if to morrow night,
Ye doe not-

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: O deare Sister-

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What ye woo'd doe
What ye desire to doe; lie with her: Devill,
What a dull man are you?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Nay I believe now,
And shall she love me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: As her life and stroke ye,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: O I will be her servant,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: 'Tis your dutie,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: And she shall have her whole will,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Yes 'tis reason,
She is a Princes, and by that rule boundles

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: What wood 'you be, for I woo'd have ye Sister
Chuse some great place about us: as her woman
Is not so fit.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: No, no, I shall find places:

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: And yet to be a Ladie of her bedchamber,
I hold not so fit neither,
Some great title, beleeve it shall be look't out.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Ye may a Dutchesse
Or such a toye, a small thing pleases me Sir

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: What you will Sister: if a neighbour Prince,
When we shall come to raigne-

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: We shall thinke on't,
Be ready at the time and in that place too,
And let me worke the rest, within this half houre;
The Princess will be going, 'tis almost morning
Away and mind your busines,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Fortune blesse us. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I doe beseech your grace to banish me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why Gentleman is she not worthy marriage?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Most worthy, Sir, where worth againe shall meet her,
But I like thicke clouds sailing slow and heavy,
Although by her drawne higher, yet shall hide her
I dare not be a traitor; and 'tis treason,
But to imagin: as you love your honourâ€”

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis her first maiden doting and if crost,
I know it kills her.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: How knowes your grace she loves him?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Her woman told me all; beside his story
Her maid Lucippe on what reason to,
And tis beyond all but enjoying.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Sir.
Even by your wisedome; by that great discretion
Ye owe to rule and orderâ€”

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: This man's mad sure,
To plead against his fortune-

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: And the King too,
Willing to have it so?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: By those dead Princes
From whose descents ye stand a starre admired at,
Lay not so base a lay upon your vertues
Take heed for honours sake take heed: the bramble
No wise man ever planted by the rose,
It canckers all her beauty; nor the vine
When her full blushes courts the sun dares any
Choke up with wanton Ivy? good my Lords,
Who builds a monument, the Basis Jasper,
And the maine body Brick?

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: Ye wrong your worth,
Ye are a Gentleman descended nobly.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: In both bloods truly noble.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Say ye were not,
My will can make ye so.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: No, never, never;
'Tis not descent, nor will of Princes does it,
'Tis Vertue which I want, 'tis Temperance,
Man, honest man is't fit your Majesty
Should call my drunkennesse, my rashnesse brother?
Or such a blessed Maid my breach of faith,
For I am most lacivious; and fell angers
In which I am also mischievous, her husband?
O Gods preserve her! I am wild as Winter,
Ambitious as the Devill: out upon me,
I hate my selfe, sir, if ye dare bestow her
Upon a Subject ye have one deserves her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But him she does not love: I know your meaning.
This young mans love unto his noble brother,
Appeares a mirrour; what must now be done Lords?
For I am gravel'd, if she have not him
She dies for certaine, if his brother misse her,
Farewell to him, and all our honours.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: He is dead sir,
Your Grace has heard of that, and strangely.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No,
I can assure ye no there was a trick in't,
Read that, and then know all; what ailes the gentleman?
Hold him; how doe ye sir? Polidor is sick ath' sudden.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sick ath' the sudden,
Extreamly ill, wondrous ill.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where did it take ye?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Here in my head sir, and my heart, for heaven sake.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Conduct him to his chamber presently,
And bid my Doctorsâ€”

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: No I shall be well sir,
I doe beseech your Grace even for the Gods sake
Remember my poore brother, I shall pray then.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away he growes more weaker still: I will do it,
Or heaven forget me ever. Now your Counsells, Exit. Polidor.
For I am at my wits end; what with you sir?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Letters from warlike Pelius.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet more troubles?
The Spartans are in Armes, and like to win all:
Supplies are sent for and the Generall;
This is more crosse then tother; come let's to him,
For he must have her, 'tis necessitie,
Or we must lose our honours, let's plead all,
For more then all is needfull, shew all reason
If love can heare a that side, if she yeild
We have fought best and won the noblest field. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: I have brought the wench, a lusty wench,
And somewhat like the Princesse.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: 'Tis the better, let's see her,
And goe you in and tell him, that her Grace
Is come to visit him? how sleeps he Stremon?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: He cannot, only thinkes, and calls on Polidor,
Swears a will not be fool'd; sometimes he rages,
And sometimes sits and muses. Exit. Stre.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: He's past all helpe sure?
How doe ye like her?

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.l: byth' masse a good round Virgin,
And at first sight resembling, she is well cloth'd too.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: But is she sound?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: Of wind and limbe, I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: You are instructed Lady?

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: Yes, and know sir
How to behave my selfe, ne're feare.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Polibius,
Where did he get this Vermin?

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: Hang him Badger,
There's not a hole free from him, whores and whores mates,
Doe all pay him obedience.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Indeed i'th' war,
His quarter was all whore, whore upon whore,
And linde with a whore, beshrew me 'tis a faire whore.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: She has smockt away her blood; but fair or foule,
Or blind or lame, that can but lift her leg up
Comes not amisse to him, he rides like a night mare,
All ages, all Religions.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Can ye state it?

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: I'le make a shift.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: He must lie with ye, Lady.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: Let him, he's not the first man I have lain with,
Nor shall not be the last.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: A comes, no more words,
She has her lesson throughly; how he views her?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Goe forward now, so, bravely, stand!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Great Lady,
How humbly I am boundâ€”

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: You shall not kneele sir,
Come, I have done you wrong; stand up my Souldier,
And thus I make amendsâ€” Kisses him.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: A plague confound ye,
Is this your state?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: 'Tis well enough.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: O Lady,
Your royall hand, your hand my dearest beauty
Is more then I must purchase: here divine one,
I dare revenge my wrongs: ha?

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: A dam'd foule one.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: The Lees of baudie prewnes: mourning gloves?
All spoyl'd by heaven.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha! who art thou?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: A shame on ye,
Ye clawing scabby whore.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I say, who art thou?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Why 'tis the Princesse sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: The divell sir,
'Tis some rogue thing.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: If this abuse be love sir,
Or I that laid aside my modestyâ€”

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: So far thou't never find it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Doe not weepe,
For if ye be the Princesse, I will love ye,
Indeed I will, and honour ye, fight for ye,
Come wipe your eyes; by heaven she stinkes; who art ta?
Stinkes like a poyson'd Ratt behind a hanging?
Woman who art ta? like a rotten Cabbage.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: Y'ar much to blame sir, 'tis the Princesse.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: How?
Shee the Princesse?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: And the loving Princesse.

sp.speaker: 1. Capt.
sp.l: Indeed the doting Princesse.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Come hither once more,
The Princesse smells like mornings breath, pure Amber,
Beyond the courted Indies in her spices
Still a dead rat by heaven; thou art a Princesse.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: What a dull whore is this?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I'le tell ye presently,
For if she be a Princesse, as she may be
And yet stink too, and strongly, I shall find her;
Fetch the Numidian Lyon I brought over,
If she be sprung from royall blood, the Lyon
He'l doe ye reverence, els

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: I beseech your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: He'l teare her all to pieces.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: I am no Princesse, sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Who brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.l: If ye confesse, wee'll hang ye.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: Good my Lord;

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Who art thou then?

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: A poore retaining whore, sir,
To one of your Lordships Captaines.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Alas poore whore,
Go, be a whore still, and stinke worse: Ha, ha ha Ex. Cloe
What fooles are these, and coxcombes? Exit. Memnon.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: I am right glad yet,
He takes it with such lightnesse.

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: Me thinkes his face too,
Is not so clouded as it was; how he lookes?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Where's your dead Rat?

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: The divell dine upon her
Lyons, why what a medicine had he gotten
To try a whore?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.p: Here's one from Polidor staies to speak with ye.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: With all; where has the Generall bin?
Hee's laughing to himselfe extreamly.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Come,
I'le tell thee how: I am glad yet he's so merry. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Chilax and Priest, Calis, Lady and Nun.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: What lights are those that enter there, still neerer?
Plague a your rotten itch, do you draw me hither
Into the Temple to betray me? was there no place
To satisfie your sin in? Gods forgive me,
Still they come forward;

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: Peace ye foole, I have found it,
'Tis the young Princesse Calis.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: 'Tis the divell
To claw us for our catterwawling.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Retire softly,
I did not looke for you these two houres, Lady,
Beshrew your hast: that way,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That goes to th'Altar?
Ye old blind Beast.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I know not any way;
Still they come nearer,
I'le in to th'Oracle;

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That's well remembred Ile in with ye;

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Doe. Exeunt Priest & Chilax.

div.stage: Enter Calis and her Traine with lights singing; Lucippe, Cleanthe.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: O faire sweet Goddesse Queene of Loves,
Soft and gentle, as thy Doves,
Humble ey'd, and ever ruing
Those poore hearts, their Loves pursuing:
O thou mother of delights,
Crowner of all happy nights,
Star of deare content, and pleasure
Of mutuall loves the endlesse treasure,
Accept this sacrifice we bring
Thou continuall youth and Spring,
Grant this Lady her desires,
And every houre, wee'll crown thy fires.
You about her all retyre,
Whilst the Princesse feedes the fire,
When your Devotions ended be
To the Oracle I will attend ye.

div.stage: Exit. Nun & draws the Curten close to Calis.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Hee will abroad.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: How does his humour hold him?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: He is now growne wondrous sad, weeps often too,
Talkes of his brother to himselfe, starts strangely.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Does he not curse?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Nor breake out in furie,
Offering some new attempt?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Neither, toth' Temple
Is all we heare of now: what there he will doe;

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: I hope repent his folly, let's be neare him.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Where are the rest?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: About a businesse
Concernes him mainly, if heav'n cure this madnesse,
He's man for ever Stremon.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Does the King know it?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Yes, and much troubled with it, is now gone
To seeke his sister out.
Come let's away then. Exeunt Eumen. Stremon, Calis.

div.stage: Enter Nun, she opens the Curtain to Calis. Calis at the Oracle, Arras.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Peace to your praiers Lady, will it please ye
To passe on to the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.p: Most humblie. Chilax & Priest in the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Doe ye heare that?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Yes, lie close.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A wildfire take ye,
What shall become of me? I shall be hang'd now.
Is this a time to shake? a halter shake ye,
Come up and juggle, come.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I am monstrous fearfull.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Up ye old gaping Oyster, up and answer,
A mouldie mange upon your chops, ye told me
I was safe here till the Bell rung.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I was prevented,
And did not looke these three houres for the Princesse.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Shall we be taken?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Speake for loves sake Chilax?
I can not, nor I dare not.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.p: I'le speake treason, for I had as lieve be hang'd for that

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Good Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Must it be sung or sed? what shall I tell 'em?
They are here? here now preparing.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: O, my conscience!

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Plague a your spurgall'd conscience, does it tyre now?
Now when it should be tuffest? I could make theeâ€”

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Save us, wee are both undone else.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Downe ye dog then,
Be quiet, and be stanch to no inundations.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Here kneele againe, and Venus grant your wishes.

lg.l: O Divine starre of Heaven,
Thou in power above the seven:
Thou sweet kindler of desires,
Till they grow to mutuall fires:
Thou, O gentle Queen that art,
Curer of each wounded heart.
Thou the fuell, and the flame;
Thou in heaven, and here the same:
Thou the wooer, and the wood:
Thou the hunger, and the food:
Thou the prayer, and the prayed;
Thou what is, or shall be said:
Thou still young, and golden tressed,
Make me by thy Answer blessed.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Now speake handsomly, and small by all meanes,
I have told ye what. Thunder.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: But I'le tell you a new tale
Now for my necke verse; I have heard thy prayers,
And marke me well.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: The Goddesse is displeased much,
The Temple shakes and totters: she appeares,
Bow, Lady, bow.

lg.l: Purge me the Temple round,
And live by this example henceforth sound
Virgin, I have seene thy teares,
Heard thy wishes and thy feares,
Thy holy Incence flew above,
Harke therefore, thy doome in love,
Had thy heart bin soft at first,
Now thou had'st alayd thy thirst:
Had thy stubborne will but bended,
All thy sorrows here had ended;
Therefore be just in love,
And strange fortune thou must prove,
And, for thou hast bin sterne and coy,
A dead love thou shalt enjoy.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: O gentle goddesse!

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.l: Rise, thy doome is sed,
And feare not; I shall please thee with the dead, Venus ascends.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Goe up into the Temple and there end
Your holy rites, the Goddesse smiles upon ye.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I'le no more Oracles, nor Miracles,
Nor no more Church worke, Ile be drawn & hang'd first:
Am not I torne a pieces with the thunder?
Death, I can scarce believe I live yet,
It gave me on the buttocks, a cruell, a huge bang,
I had as lieue a had 'em scratcht with dog-whips;
Be quiet henceforth, now ye feele the end on't,
I would advise ye my old friends the good gentlewoman
Is strucken dumbe and there her grace sits mumping
Like an old Ape eating a Brawn; sure the good Goddesse
Knew my intent was honest, to save the Princesse.
And how we young men are entic'd to wickednesse
By these lewd women, I had paid for't els too:
I am monstrous holy now, and cruel fearefull,
O! 'twas a plaguy thump, charg'd with a vengeance.
sp.stage: Enter Siphax walkes softly over the Stage, and goes in.
sp.l: Woo'd I were well at home; the best is 'tis not day:
Who's that? ha? Siphax? I'le be with you anon, sir,
Ye shall be Oracled I warrant ye,
And thunderd too as well as I: your Lordship
sp.stage: Enter Memnon, Eumenes, Stremon, and two carrying Torches.
sp.l: Must needs enjoy the Princesse, yes, ha! torches?
And Memnon comming this way, he's dog mad,
And ten to one appearing thus unto him,
Hee worries me, I must goe by him.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Aske me no further questions; what art thou?
How dost thou stare? stand off; nay looke upon me,
I doe not shake, nor feare thee.â€” Drawes his sword.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A will kill me,
This is for Church worke.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why dost thou appeare now?
Thou wert fairly slain: I know thee Diocles,
And know thine envie to mine honour: butâ€”

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Stay Memnon,
I am a Spirit, and thou canst not hurt me.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: This is the voyce of Chilax.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: What makes he thus?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: 'Tis true that I was slaine in field, but fowly
By multitudes not manhood: therefore marke me,
I doe appeare againe to quit mine honour,
And on thee single.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I accept the challenge.
Where?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: On the Stigian banks

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Four dayes hence.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Goe noble Ghost, I will attend.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I thanke ye.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Ye have sav'd your throat and handsomly:
Farwell sir. exit Chi.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Sing me the Battell of Pelusium,
In which this Worthie died.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: This will spoile all, and make him worse
Then ere he was, sitt downe sir,
And give your selfe to rest.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: ARme, arme, arme, arm, the Scouts are all come in
Keepe your rankes close and now your honours win.
Behold from yonder hill, the foe appeares,
Bowes, bills glaves arrowes shields, and Speares,
Like a darke wood he comes, or tempest powring,
O view the wings of horse, the meadows scowring,
The vant-guard marches bravely, hark the Drumsâ€” dub, dub,
They meet they meet, now the Battell comes,
See how the Arrows fly
That darken all the skie,
Harke how the Trumpets sound,
Hark how the hills rebound,â€” Tara-tara-tara.
Hark how the horses charge: in boyes in boyes in,- tara, tara,
The Battell totters; now the wounds begin,
O how they cry,
O how they dy.
Roome for the valiant Memnon, arm'd with thunder,
See how he breakes the rankes asunder:
They fly they flie Eumenes has the Chace,
And brave Polibius, makes good his place.
To the plaines to the Woode,
To the Rocks to the floods,
They fly for succour: Follow, follow, follow, Hey, hey.
Harke how the Souldiers hollow
Brave Diocles is dead,
And all his Souldiers fled,
The battell's won, and lost,
That many a life hath cost.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Now forward to the Temple. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Are ye gone?
How have I scapt this morning? by what miracle?
Sure I am ordain'd for some brave end.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: How is it?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Come, 'tis as well as can be.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: But is it possible
This should be true you tell me?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: 'Tis most certaine.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: Such a grosse Asse to love the Princesse?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Peace,
Pull your robe close about ye: you are perfect
In all I taught ye.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: Sure.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Gods give thee good luck,
'Tis strange my braines should still be beating knaverie
For all these dangers: but they are needfull mischiefes,
And such are Nuts to me, and I must doe 'em,
You will remember meâ€”

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: By this kisse Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chilax.
sp.l: No more of that, I feare another Thunder.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: We are not i'th' Temple man.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Peace, here he comes,
Now to our businesse handsomely: away now. exit Chilax and Cloe.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: 'Twas sure the Princesse, for he kneel'd unto her,
And she lookt every way: I hope the Oracle
Has made me happy: me I hope she lookt for.
sp.stage: Enter Chilax and Cloe at the other doore.
sp.l: Fortune, I will so honour thee, Love so adore thee,
She is here againe lookes round about againe too,
'Tis done, I know 'tis done; 'tis Chilax with her,
And I shall know of him; whos's that?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Speake softly,
The Princesse from the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: She views me,
By heav'n she beckens me.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Come neare, she woo'd have ye.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: O royall Lady. Kisses her hand.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: She wills ye read that, for belike she's bound to silence
For such a time; she is wondrous gracious to ye.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Heav'n make me thankfull.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: She woo'd have ye read it, He Reads.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Siphax, the will of Heaven hath cast me on thee
To be thy wife, whose will must be obay'd:
Use me with honour, I shall love thee dearly,
And make thee understand thy worths hereafter;
Convey me to a secret Ceremony,
That both our hearts and loves may be united,
And use no language, till before my brother
We both appeare, where I will shew the Oracle,
For till that time I am bound, I must not answer.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: O happy I!

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ye are a made man.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: But Chilax
Where are her women?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: None but your Graces Sister,
Because she would have it privat to the world yet,
Knowes of this businesse.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: I shall thanke the Chilax,
Thou art a carefull man.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Your Graces servant.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: I'le find a fit place for thee.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: If you will not,
There's a good Lady will, she points yee forward,
Away and take your fortune, not a word sir,
So, you are greas'd I hope. Exit Siph. & Cloe. manet Chi.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Stremon, Foole, Picus.
Where have you left your Lord?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: I'th' Temple, Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Why are ye from him?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Why the King is with him,
And all the Lords.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Is not the Princesse there too.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Yes,
And the strangest coile amongst 'em: She weeps bitterly;
The King entreats, and frownes, my Lord like Autumne
Drops off his hopes by handfulls, all the Temple
Sweats with this Agonie.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Where's young Polidor?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Dead as they said o'th' sudden.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Dead?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: For certaine,
But not yet knowne abroad,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: There's a new trouble;
A brave young man he was; but we must all die.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Did not the Generall meet you this morning
Like a tall stallion Nun?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: No more a that Boy.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: You had been ferreting.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That's all one, Foole;
My Master foole that taught my wits to traffique,
What has your wisdome done? how have you profited?
Out with your Audit, come: you are not emptie,
Put out mine eye with twelve pence? do you shaker?
What thinke you of this shaking? here's with coxcombe
Ha boyes? ha my fine rascalls, here's a Ring, Pulls out a Purse.
How right they goe?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: O let me ring the fore-bell.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And here are thumpers, Chickens, golden rogues,
â—it wit ye rascalls.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: I have a Sty here Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I have no gold to cure it, not a penny,
Not one crosse Cavalier; we are dull Sou'diers,
Grosse, heavy-headed fellowes; fight for victualls?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Why; ye are the spirits of the time.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: By no meanes.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: The valiant firie.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Fy, fie no.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Be-lee-me sir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I woo'd I could sir.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: I will satisfie ye.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: But I will not content you; alas poore boy,
Thou shewst an honest nature weepes for thy Master,
There's a red rogue to buy thee handkerchers.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: A was an honest Gentleman, I have lost too.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ye have indeed your labour Foole; but Stremon,
Doest thou want money too? no virtue living?
No firking out at fingers ends?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: It seemes so.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Will ye all serve me?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Yes, when ye are Lord Generall,
For lesse I will not goe.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: There's gold for thee then,
Thou hast a souldiers minde, Foole.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: Here, your first man.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I will give thee for thy wit, for 'tis a fine wit,
A daintie diving wit, hold up; just nothing,
Goe graze i'th' commons, yet I am mercifull
There's six pence; buy a Saucer, steale an old gowne,
And beg i'th' Temple for a Prophet, come away boyes,
Let's see how things are carried, Foole, up sirra,
You may chance get a dinner: Boy your preferment
I'le undertake, for your brave Masters sake,
You shall not perish.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Please me well Foole,
And you shall light my pipes: Away to th' Temple.
But stay, the Kings here, sport upon sport Boyes.

div.stage: Enter King, Lords Siphax kneeling, Cloe with a Vaile.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What would you have Captaine,
Speake suddenly, for I am wondrous busie.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: A Pardon, Royall sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: For that,
Which was heav'ns will, should not be mine alone sir;
My marrying with this Lady.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It needs no Pardon,
For marriage is no sin.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Not in it selfe, sir,
But in presuming too much: Yet heav'n knowes
So does the Oracle that cast it on me,
Andâ€” the Princesse, royall sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What Princesse?

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: O be not angrie, my dread King, your Sister.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My sister? she's i'th' Temple man.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: She is here sir.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The Captain's mad, she is kneeling at the Altar.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I know she is, with all my heart good Captain,
I do forgive ye both: be unvail'd Lady; Puts off her vaile
Will ye have more forgivenes? the mans frantick,
Come let's goe bring her out: God give yee joy sir.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.p: How? Cloe? my old Cloe? Exit. King, Lords.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: Even the same sir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Gods give your manhood much content.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: The Princesse
Lookes something mustie since her comming over.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: 'Twere good, youl'd brush her over.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: Fooles and Fidlers
Make sport at my abuse too.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: O 'tis the nature
Of us Fooles to make bold with one another,
But you are wise, brave sirs.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Cheere up your Princesse,
Believe it sir, the King will not be angry,
Or say he were; why 'twas the Oracle,
The Oracle, and like your Grace, the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: And who, most mighty Siphax?

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: With mine owne whore.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: With whom els should ye marry speak your conscience,
Will ye transgresse the law of Armes, that ever
Rewards the Souldier with his owne sins?

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: Devills.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: Ye had my maiden-head my youth, my sweetnes,
Is it not justice then?â€”

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: I see it must be,
But by this hand. I'le hang a lock upon thee.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: You shall not need, my honesty shall doe it.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: If there be wars in all the worldâ€”

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: I'le with ye,
For you know, I have bin a souldier,
Come, curse on: when I need another Oracle.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Send for me Siphax, I'le fit ye with a Princesse,
And so to both your honours.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: And your graces.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: The Devill grace ye all.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: God a mercy Chilax,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Shall we laugh halfe an houre now?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: No the King comes,
And all the traine.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Away then, our Act's ended. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter King, Calis. Memnon and Cleanthe, Curtisan, Lords.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You know he do's deserve ye, loves ye dearly,
You know what bloody violence had us'd The Hearse ready Polidor, Eumenes & Captains
Upon himselfe, but that his brother crost it,
You know the same thoughts still inhabit in him
And covet to take birth: Look on him Lady,
The wars have not so far consum'd him yet,
Cold age disabled him, or sicknesse sunk him
To be abhorr'd: looke on his Honour sister,
That beares no stamp of time, no wrinkles on it,
No sad demolishment, nor death can reach it:
Looke with the eyes of heaven that nightlie waken,
To view the wonders of my glorious Maker,
And not the weaknesse: looke with your vertuous eyes,
And then clad royaltie in all his conquests;
His matchlesse love hung with a thousand merits
Eternall youth attending, Fame and Fortune,
Time and Oblivion vexing at his vertues,
He shall appeare a miracle: looke on our dangers,
Looke on the publique ruine.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: O, deare brother.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fie, let us not like proud and greedy waters
Gaine, to give off againe: this is our Sea,
And you his Cynthia, govern him, take heed,
His stouds have bin as hie, and full as any,
And gloriously now is got up to the girdle,
The Kingdomes he hath purchas'd; noble Sister,
Take not your vertue from him, O take heed
We ebbe not now to nothing, take heed Calis.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: The wil of heaven not mine, which must not alter,
And my eternall doome for ought I know
Is fixt upon me; alas, I must love nothing.
Nothing that loves againe must I be blest with:
The gentle Vine climbs up the Oke and clips him.
And when the stroke comes, yet they fall together;
Death death must I enjoy, and live to love him,
O noble Sir!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Those teares are some reward yet,
Pray let me wed your sorrowes.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Take 'em Souldier,
They are fruitfull ones, lay but a fight upon 'em,
And strait they will conceive to infinites;
I told ye what, ye could find 'em,
Roome before there. Knock.

div.stage: Enter Funerall, Captaines following, and Eumenes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now, what's this? more drops to th'Ocean?
Whose body's this?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: The noble Polidor,
This speakes his death.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My Brother dead?

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: O Goddesse!
O cruell, cruell Venus, here's my fortune.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Read Captaine.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Read aloude: farewell my follies. Eumen reades

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: Be wise, as you are beauteous, love with judgement,
And look with clear eyes on my noble Brother,
Value desert and vertue, they are Jewells,
Fit for your worth and wearing: take heed Lady,
The Gods reward ingratitude most grievous;
Remember me no more, or if you must,
Seeke me in noble Memnons love, I dwell there:
I durst not live, because I durst not wrong him,
I can no more, make mee eternall happy
With looking downe upon your loves.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And did'st thou die for me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Excellent vertue!
What will ye now doe?

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Dwell for euer here sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: For me deare Polidor? Ã´ worthy young man!
O love, love, love, love above recompence!
Infinite love, infinite honesty!
Good Lady leave, you must have no share here,
Take home your sorrowes: here's enough to store me,
Brave glorious griefes! was ever such a brother?
Turne all the stories over in the world yet,
And search through all the memories of mankind,
And find me such a friend; h'as out-done all.
Outstript 'em sheerely, all, all, thou hast Polidor,
To die for me; why, as I hope for happinesse,
'Twas one of the rarest thought on things
The bravest, and carried beyond compasse of our actions,
I wonder how he hit it, a young man too,
In all the blossomes of his youth and beautie,
In all the fulnesse of his veines and wishes
Woed by that Paradice, that would catch heaven;
It starts me extreamly, thou blest Ashes,
Thou faithfull monument, where loue and friendship
Shall while the world is, worke new miracles.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: O! let me speake too.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No not yet, thou man,
For we are but mans shadowes, only man,
I have not words to utter him; speake Lady,
I'le thinke a while.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: The Goddesse grants me this yet,
I shall enjoy the dead: no tombe shall hold thee
But these two armes, no Trickments but my teares
Over thy Hearse, my sorrowes like sad armes
Shall hang for ever: on the tuffest Marble
Mine eyes shall weepe thee out an Epitaph,
Love at thy feet shall kneele, his smart bow broken;
Faith at thy head, youth and the Graces mourners;
O sweet young man!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now I begin to melt too.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Have ye enough yet Lady? roome for a gamster
To my fond Love, and all those idle fancies
A long farwell, thou diedst for me deare Polidor,
To give me peace, thou hast eternall glory,
I stay and talke here; I will kisse thee first,
And now I'le follow thee. Polidor rises.

sp.speaker: Pollidor.
sp.l: Hold, for heavens sake!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha!
Does he live?
Dost thou deceive me?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thus farre,
Yet for your good, and honour.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now deare sister;

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: The Oracle is ended, noble sir,
Dispose, me now as you please.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: You are mine then?

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: With all the joyes that may be.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Your consent sir;

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ye have it freely.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Walke along with me then,
And as you love me, love my will.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: I will so.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Here worthy Brother, take this vertuous Princesse,
Ye have deserv'd her nobly, she will love ye,
And when my life shall bring ye peace, as she does,
Command it, ye shall have it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Sir, I thanke ye.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I never found such goodnesse in such yeares.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thou shalt not over-doe me, though I die for't,
O how I love thy goodnesse, my best brother,
You have given me here a treasure to enrich me,
Would make the worthiest King alive a begger,
What may I give you back againe?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Your love sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And you shall have it, even my dearest love,
My first, my noblest love, take her againe, sir,
She is yours, your honesty has over-run me,
She loves ye, lov'st her not? excellent Princesse,
Injoy thy wish, and now get Generalls.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: As ye love heaven, love him, she is only yours, sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: As ye love heaven, love him, she is only yours, sir;
My Lord, the King.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: He will undoe himselfe sir,
And must without her perish; who shall fight then?
Who shall protect your Kingdome?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Give me hearing,
And after that beliefe, were she my soule
(As I doe love her equall) all my victories,
And all the living names I have gain'd by warre,
And loving him that good, that vertuous good man,
That only worthy of the name of brother,
I would resigne all freely, 'tis all love
To me, all marriage rites, the joy of issues
To know him fruitfull, that has been so faithfull.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: This is the noblest difference-take your choise sister.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: I see they are so brave, and noble both,
I know not which to looke on.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Chuse discreetly,
And vertue guide ye, there all the world in one man
Stands at the marke.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: There all mans honestie,
The sweetnesse of all youthâ€”

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O God's!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My Armour,
By all the God's she's yours; my armes, I say,
And I beseech your Grace, give me imployment,
That shall be now my Mistresse: here my Courtship.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ye shall have any thing.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Vertuous Lady,
Remember me, your servant now; Young man,
You cannot over-reach me in your goodnesse;
O love! how sweet thou look'st now? and how gentle,
I should have slubber'd thee, and stain'd thy beauty;
Your hand, your hand sir;

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take her, and Heaven blesse her.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: 'Tis your will sir, nothing of my merit;
And as your royall gift, I take this blessing.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And I from heaven this gentleman: thanks Goddess.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: So ye are pleas'd now Lady;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Now or never.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My cold stiffe carkasse, would have frozen ye,
Warres, warres.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ye shall have warres.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My next brave battell
I dedicate to your bright honour (sister,)
Give me a favour, that the world may know
I am your souldier.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: This, and all faire Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And he that beares this from me, must strike boldly.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I do forgive thee: be honest, no more wench.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come now to Revells, this blest day shall prove
The happy crown of noble Faith and Love. Exeunt.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: TO please all's impossible, and to despaire
Ruins our selves, and dampes the Writers care:
Would we knew what to doe, or say, or when
To find the mindes here equall with the men:
But we must venture; now to Sea we goe,
Faire fortune with us, give us roome, and blow;
Remember ye'ar all venturers; and in this Play
How many twelve-pences ye have 'stow'd this day:
Remember for returne of your delight,
We launch, and plough through stormes of feare, and spight:
Give us your fore-windes fairely, fill our wings,
And steere us right, and as the Saylors sing,
Loden with Wealth, on wanton seas, so we
Shall make our home-bound-voyage chearfully;
And you our noble Merchants, for your treasure
Share equally the fraught, we run for pleasure.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: HEre lyes the doubt now, let our Playes be good,
Our owne care sayling equall in this Flood;
Our preparations new, new our Attire,
Yet here we are becalm'd still, still i'th' mire,
Here we stick fast; Is there no way to cleare
This passage of your judgement, and our feare,
No mittigation of that law? Brave friends,
Consider we are yours, made for your ends,
And every thing preserves it selfe, each will
If not perverse, and crooked, utters still
The best of that it ventures in: have care
Ev'n for your pleasures sake, of what we are,
And doe not ruine all: You may frowne still.
But 'tis the nobler way, to check the will.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
